fieldData.title: Corona bonus in several industrial sectors
fieldData.calc_minorCategory: Ensuring business continuity and support for essential services
fieldData.calc_subMinorCategory: Remuneration and rewards for workers in essential services
fieldData.descriptionBackgroundInfo: As in many European countries, during the first lockdown in Austria in spring 2020, employers and employees were asked by the federal government to resort to home office if and where possible, in order to keep physical contacts at a minimum. While this was feasible for many office workers, this was far less possible for industrial workers who had to continue to go to their work places, putting them at a higher risk of catching COVID-19.
fieldData.descriptionContentOfMeasure: In order to compensate for their increased burden and outstanding commitment during those times, in many industrial sectors, a Corona-bonus of €150 was negotiated in this spring's annual collective bargaining rounds, e.g. in the electrical and electronics industry, in the chemical industry, and in the shoe and textile industries. * In all these sectors, a wage increase of 1.6% (collectively agreed minimum wages, actual wages and apprenticeship compensation) was agreed. * In the wood processing and sawmill industries, a Corona-bonus of €130 for blue-collar workers and €300 for white-collar workers was agreed upon, as well as regular wage increases (actual, minimum, apprentices) of 1.6%. * In the leather and suitcase industry, increases of 1.45% and a Corona-bonus of €100 were agreed upon by the sectoral social partners. * In the paper industry, a higher Corona-bonus of €460 (with an option to increase it to €760 as recommended by the CA partners) and €340 for apprentices was negotiated, also with 1.6% regular increases.* In the pattern-setting metal industry bargaining rounds in autumn 2020, a recommendation to pay a Corona-bonus of €150 was given and an increase of 1.45% (minimum and actual wages, apprenticeship compensation) was negotiated.
fieldData.descriptionUseOfMeasure: Around 120,000 employees work in those industrial sectors which conducted their annual bargaining rounds in spring.
fieldData.descriptionInvolvementOfSocialPartners: The specific sectoral social partners negotiated the annual collective bargaining rounds, as requested by their institutional setting.
fieldData.statusOfRegulation: New aspects included into existing measure
